PAGE THREE

Bender To Join
National Center
For Atom Study

Bird-Dogging Bad?
Have A Drink, Pal!

Dr. Michael A. Bender, who
received his PhD. degree in
biology from the Johns Hopkins
University in 1956, has recently
been added to the staff of the
Biology Division of Oak Ridge
National Laboratory, Oak Ridge,
Tennessee.
Dr. Bender remained at Johns
Hopkins as a post-doctoral fellow working under the direction
of Dr. H. Bentley Glass, professor of biology. His research on
the effects of radiation on living cells was supported by the
National Institute of Health and
the Atomic Energy Commission.
The Oak Ridge National Laboratory, one of the world's largest
laboratories engaged in basic research and the development of
nuclear reactors, is operated by
Union Carbide Corporation for
the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission.

Cultural Auguries
Baltimore's collective mentality vacillates between
an insalubrious hill-billishness and a superfluitant, perspicacious ne-plus-ultra culture. Pervading these intellectual extremities is the .city's Old South provincialism;
smug, tradition-directed, exclusively Baltimore-first, it
represents a city which never succeeded in drawing itself
out of a Victorian womb.
Though it never succeeded and hence has preserved
its pedestrian inveiglement, Baltimore has tried. The
Civic Center, Ford's and the Lyric, the Symphony, Walters
and the Museum of Art, Pratt Library—the list closes
on those institutions which have tried to bring culture
here and keep it here, but are financially starved and
publically ignored.
In renewing its own previously lackadasical program
in the arts through the Poetry Festival, Johns Hopkins
promises to not only augment its curriculurri but also to
amplify and lead the city's cultural opportunities.
If cooperative programs between Ford's, the Lyric,
Symphony, Walters, Museum of Art, Goucher and Johns
Hopkins can be devised and enacted, it is entirely probable
that culture's future here would have good auguries.

Decision Rendered
Word comes from the librarian's office that, after
three weeks of enthusiastic response to the Sunday library
hours, the library will remain open on Sundays until the
students prove they are no longer interested in using the
facilities on the Sabbath.
This announcement is undoubtedly a victory for
the Honor Commission, which originally proposed the idea
some years ago, but the real credit and applause must go
to the Student Council and especially President Charlie
Ginsberg, who worked hard and effectively to secure the
support of many who felt the plan would fall flat on
its face.
Perhaps grudgingly, we must admit that the Student
Council has made a tangible contribution which definitely
filled a need of the students.
However, while handing out a few bouquets, we also
caution the librarian's office that a too strict interpretation of its warning that a lag in use will result in abandonment of the program will only lead to unneeded furor.
The enormous turnout of late has been due largely to
the onslaught of mid-semester examinations, and certainly
the interest will lag to an extent when the exam anxiety
passes. But we feel that if seventy students will troop
through the rain and slush as they did Sunday then
the question of whether the library should ever be closed
on • a Sunday afternoon has been answered with a
resounding—NO!

ANYONE FOR FOOTBALL?
When Pancho Sigafoos, sophomore, pale and sensitive, first saw
Willa Ludowic, freshman, lithe as a hazel wand and rosy as the
dawn, he hemmed not; neither did he haw. "I adore you," he
said without preliminary.
"Thanks, hey," said Willa, flinging her apron over her face
modestly."What position do you play?"
"Position?" said Paiicho, looking at her askance. (The
askance is a ligament just behind the ear.) ,
the football team," said Willa.
"Football!" sneered Pancho, his young lip curling. "Football
is violence, and violence
is the death of the mind. I am not a
football player. I am a poet!"
"So long, buster," said Willa.
"Wait!" cried Pancho, clutching her damask forearm.
She placed a foot on his pelvis and wrenched herself free.
I only go with football players,"she said, and walked,shimmering, into the gathering dusk.

It might be argued that the
Y performs rather well the task
of providing a religious atmosphere on the Hopkins campus.

There are many places of worship

campus.
And furthermore, there is no
reason for introducing an element that is sectarian in a nonsectarian manner to our campus.
It is a well established fact that
Hopkins is not noted for its
religiosity.
If the men who make the University's policy had, in the past,
deemed it necessary to have a
department of religion, they
would have seen to its establishment.

Harrier Victors
Down Two Foes
In Recent Meet

Fate Foils Footballer
After Initial Victories

By RICHARD ESTEVES
The Blue Jay harriers scored
an impressive victory over Washington and Haverford last Saturday in a triangular meet at the
Washington course.
The highlight of the race was
Morris Jones' record-breaking
finish. Jones led the field in
15:50, shattering the old standard set by Loyola's Paul Sherman
in 1956. Sherman's 16:07 mark
was also broken by Don Smilovitz, who finished second in
15:56.
The final results were Hopkins,
18; Haverford, 57; and host
Washington, 58 (low score wins).
Hopkins, with its fine overall
strength, swept five of the first
seven places. The Jays are now
5-1 on the season, their only setback coming at the hands of
Loyola.
This Saturday Hopkins travels
to Swarthmore where the Blue
Jays engage the Pennsylvania
team in a dual meet. Coach
Brown has commented optimistically: "If we win this meet, we
could very well go undefeated
for the remainder of the season."
The freshman harriers closed
their season with a loss to Mt.
St. Joseph, the Blue Jays being
edged out by a 26-29 score. Fitzpatrick of Hopkins remained undefeated, but the team was not
as fortunate. Their only victory
came over Bainbridge Prep as the
frosh finished the season with a
1-3 record.

Emil R. San Soucie got his A.B. degree
from Harvard in 1954. He joined the
Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania in early 1955. Today, three short
years later, he's in charge of 35 employees in a West Philadelphia business
office serving 43,000 customers.
"It's an interesting job," says Emil.
"I guess .that's because people are interesting. Every day, I talk with customers — and no two are alike. They
all have different problems and service
needs. That makes every working day
different and stimulating for me.
"There's also a great sales opportunity. Homes and businesses need the
convenience and efficiency that up-todate telephone facilities offer. It's a

strong story, and we tell it often and
enthusiastically.
"Outside the office, I'm active in local
civic affairs. And I'm always a bit awed
— and pleased — by the respect people
show for the telephone company and for
a young fellow in my position.
"I don't know where a man like me
with management ambitions has a better
opportunity."

Casting has been completed
and rehearsals have been started
.for the first full-scale Barnstormer production of this year.
R.U.R., which will be given in

The lead role in R.U.R., which
stands for "Rossum's Universal
Robots," has been alloted to
Leigh Noyes, who will portray
Harry Domin, general manager
of Rossum's Universal Robot
Company.
R.U.R. deals with the conquest
of the human race by robots.
Rossum's Universal Robots is a
company which manufactures
humanoid .robots, that is, robots
which are equal to humans in all
respects, except that they have
no souls, desires or feelings.
Human Robots

the island on which R.U.R. has
its main plant and marries
DOMi7i, she attempts to have
robots made which will have
human feelings. Several hundred
of these partially humanized
robots are successfully produced,
anti these provide enough ringleaders to organize a revolt
against the humans.
No mercy is shown by the
robots, and soon Almquist is the
only human being left alive on
the earth. He is held by the
robots with the hope that he can
reproduce the secret formula,
which is necessary for new robots
to be made, since the old ones
are slowly deteriorating. He finds
this an impossible task, but the

Bender To Join
National Center
For Atom Study

Bird-Dogging Bad?
Have A Drink, Pal!

Dr. Michael A. Bender, who
received his PhD. degree in
biology from the Johns Hopkins
University in 1956, has recently
been added to the staff of the
Biology Division of Oak Ridge
National Laboratory, Oak Ridge,
Tennessee.
Dr. Bender remained at Johns
Hopkins as a post-doctoral fellow working under the direction
of Dr. H. Bentley Glass, professor of biology. His research on
the effects of radiation on living cells was supported by the
National Institute of Health and
the Atomic Energy Commission.
The Oak Ridge National Laboratory, one of the world's largest
laboratories engaged in basic research and the development of
nuclear reactors, is operated by
Union Carbide Corporation for
the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission.

Cultural Auguries
Baltimore's collective mentality vacillates between
an insalubrious hill-billishness and a superfluitant, perspicacious ne-plus-ultra culture. Pervading these intellectual extremities is the .city's Old South provincialism;
smug, tradition-directed, exclusively Baltimore-first, it
represents a city which never succeeded in drawing itself
out of a Victorian womb.
Though it never succeeded and hence has preserved
its pedestrian inveiglement, Baltimore has tried. The
Civic Center, Ford's and the Lyric, the Symphony, Walters
and the Museum of Art, Pratt Library—the list closes
on those institutions which have tried to bring culture
here and keep it here, but are financially starved and
publically ignored.
In renewing its own previously lackadasical program
in the arts through the Poetry Festival, Johns Hopkins
promises to not only augment its curriculurri but also to
amplify and lead the city's cultural opportunities.
If cooperative programs between Ford's, the Lyric,
Symphony, Walters, Museum of Art, Goucher and Johns
Hopkins can be devised and enacted, it is entirely probable
that culture's future here would have good auguries.

Decision Rendered
Word comes from the librarian's office that, after
three weeks of enthusiastic response to the Sunday library
hours, the library will remain open on Sundays until the
students prove they are no longer interested in using the
facilities on the Sabbath.
This announcement is undoubtedly a victory for
the Honor Commission, which originally proposed the idea
some years ago, but the real credit and applause must go
to the Student Council and especially President Charlie
Ginsberg, who worked hard and effectively to secure the
support of many who felt the plan would fall flat on
its face.
Perhaps grudgingly, we must admit that the Student
Council has made a tangible contribution which definitely
filled a need of the students.
However, while handing out a few bouquets, we also
caution the librarian's office that a too strict interpretation of its warning that a lag in use will result in abandonment of the program will only lead to unneeded furor.
The enormous turnout of late has been due largely to
the onslaught of mid-semester examinations, and certainly
the interest will lag to an extent when the exam anxiety
passes. But we feel that if seventy students will troop
through the rain and slush as they did Sunday then
the question of whether the library should ever be closed
on • a Sunday afternoon has been answered with a
resounding—NO!

ANYONE FOR FOOTBALL?
When Pancho Sigafoos, sophomore, pale and sensitive, first saw
Willa Ludowic, freshman, lithe as a hazel wand and rosy as the
dawn, he hemmed not; neither did he haw. "I adore you," he
said without preliminary.
"Thanks, hey," said Willa, flinging her apron over her face
modestly."What position do you play?"
"Position?" said Paiicho, looking at her askance. (The
askance is a ligament just behind the ear.) ,
the football team," said Willa.
"Football!" sneered Pancho, his young lip curling. "Football
is violence, and violence
is the death of the mind. I am not a
football player. I am a poet!"
"So long, buster," said Willa.
"Wait!" cried Pancho, clutching her damask forearm.
She placed a foot on his pelvis and wrenched herself free.
I only go with football players,"she said, and walked,shimmering, into the gathering dusk.

There are some organizations
on this campus which only serve
the purpose of providing a title
for their officers and for those
who are merely members, another organization with which
to impress potential employers.
It is not the purpose of this
letter to evaluate all such groups;
rather, we will select one and
attempt to discover whether such
an organization serves a useful
function on this campus.
The organization we have
chosen as the one example of
relative uselessness is the Young
Christian
Association
Men's
(which in the sections that follow will be referred to simply as
the Y). You may ask "why this
group in particular?" At a glance
it would seem that they are
doing an effective job. And here
we pose the second question:
what job?
No Need For Y
It might be argued that the
Y performs rather well the task
of providing a religious atmosphere on the Hopkins campus.
But there would seem to be little
purpose for this atmosphere.
There are many places of worship
located within the vicinity of the
campus.
And furthermore, there is no
reason for introducing an element that is sectarian in a nonsectarian manner to our campus.
It is a well established fact that
Hopkins is not noted for its
religiosity.
If the men who make the University's policy had, in the past,
deemed it necessary to have a
department of religion, they
would have seen to its establishment.

Middle-Atlantic Conference victories of the season last week

and Delaware. The Jays are 2-0

overall record of 4-2-0. Hopkins
plays only four games in the

"team victories, achieved by determination and thinking soccer."

were up against one of the better
teams in the Mid-Atlantic loop,
and Cochrane thinks that "we
were very fortunate to shut them
out."

Harrier Victors
Down Two Foes
In Recent Meet

Fate Foils Footballer
After Initial Victories

By RICHARD ESTEVES
The Blue Jay harriers scored
an impressive victory over Washington and Haverford last Saturday in a triangular meet at the
Washington course.
The highlight of the race was
Morris Jones' record-breaking
finish. Jones led the field in
15:50, shattering the old standard set by Loyola's Paul Sherman
in 1956. Sherman's 16:07 mark
was also broken by Don Smilovitz, who finished second in
15:56.
The final results were Hopkins,
18; Haverford, 57; and host
Washington, 58 (low score wins).
Hopkins, with its fine overall
strength, swept five of the first
seven places. The Jays are now
5-1 on the season, their only setback coming at the hands of
Loyola.
This Saturday Hopkins travels
to Swarthmore where the Blue
Jays engage the Pennsylvania
team in a dual meet. Coach
Brown has commented optimistically: "If we win this meet, we
could very well go undefeated
for the remainder of the season."
The freshman harriers closed
their season with a loss to Mt.
St. Joseph, the Blue Jays being
edged out by a 26-29 score. Fitzpatrick of Hopkins remained undefeated, but the team was not
as fortunate. Their only victory
came over Bainbridge Prep as the
frosh finished the season with a
1-3 record.

Emil R. San Soucie got his A.B. degree
from Harvard in 1954. He joined the
Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania in early 1955. Today, three short
years later, he's in charge of 35 employees in a West Philadelphia business
office serving 43,000 customers.
"It's an interesting job," says Emil.
"I guess .that's because people are interesting. Every day, I talk with customers — and no two are alike. They
all have different problems and service
needs. That makes every working day
different and stimulating for me.
"There's also a great sales opportunity. Homes and businesses need the
convenience and efficiency that up-todate telephone facilities offer. It's a

strong story, and we tell it often and
enthusiastically.
"Outside the office, I'm active in local
civic affairs. And I'm always a bit awed
— and pleased — by the respect people
show for the telephone company and for
a young fellow in my position.
"I don't know where a man like me
with management ambitions has a better
opportunity."
•
Many young men are finding interesting
and rewarding careers in the Bell Telephone Companies. There are opportunities for you, too. Talk with the Bell

campus. Read the Bell Telephone booklet on file in your Placement Office.

Rossum's Universal Robots is a
company which manufactures

which are equal to humans in all

no souls, desires or feelings.

anti these provide enough ringleaders to organize a revolt

robots with the hope that he can
